questions.text: What is the best test for the diagnosis of rotavirus?
questions.solution:
• Rotavirus are virus which causes diarrhea in infant and children
  • It transmits through the feco oral route.
  • Vomiting and diarrhea, dehydration occur, it lasts for 2 to 8 days.
  • Diagnosis is generally done by Clinical feature.
  • In Lab diagnosis, PCR can be done but it is costly
  • Viral antigen can be detected in stool - can be done
  • Light microscopy is wrong option because no virus can be seen in light microscopy
  • Antigen in blood is the wrong option because antigen is secreted in stool, it does not go to blood.

questions.text: Wedge shaped hair perforation in the hair shaft is seen in
questions.solution:
Trichophyton mentagrophytesis a dermatophyte fungus that is known for causing infections in the hair, skin, and nails. One of the characteristic features of this fungus, when it infects the hair, is the wedge-shaped hair perforation. This perforation occurs due to the fungus invading the hair shaft and causing damage.

(A)Trichophyton rubrum: This is another dermatophyte but it typically causes athlete's foot, ringworm, and nail infections. It does not produce wedge-shaped perforations in hair.

(C)Microsporum canis: A dermatophyte commonly associated with ringworm in animals and humans. It primarily affects the skin and scalp, but does not exhibit wedge-shaped hair perforations.

(D)Microsporum audouinii: This dermatophyte is known for causing tinea capitis (ringworm of the scalp) and often produces grayish-white scales on the scalp, but not wedge-shaped hair perforations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese Encephalitis?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis is found in Asia and the west pacific, in this disease there is brain swelling.

Japanese encephalitis is a virus(Flavivirus)spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes. It is more common in rural and agricultural areas.

Most cases are mild, rarely it causes serious brain swelling with sudden headache, high fever and disorientation.

Pigs are amplifier host

This virus transmitted by Culex vishnui

Vaccination of pigs can control transmission.

Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts. Human infection is a 'dead end' event and occurs when the infected mosquitoes reach high density.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenkii is caused by thermally dimorphic fungus sporothrix schenckii.

It is naturally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss and plants. It usually affects farmers, gardeners and agricultural workers. This fungal disease usually affects the skin although rare forms can affect the lungs, joints, bone and CNS.

Fungus enters through small cuts and abrasion in the skin to cause the infection.

Because roses can spread the disease, it is one of a few diseases referred to as rose thorn or rose gardener's disease.

(A): Blastomyces dermatitidis - Broad-based budding of Blastomyces (same size as RBC). Inflammatory lung disease Disseminates to bone/ skin (verrucous lesions C, may mimic SCC).

(C): Coccidioides Immitis - Spherule filled with endospores of Coccidioides (much larger than RBC). Disseminates to bone/ skin Erythema nodosum (desert bumps) or multiforme Arthralgias (desert rheumatism). Can cause meningitis.

Associated with dust exposure in endemic areas (eg, archeological excavations, earthquakes).

(D): Paracoccidioides Brasiliensis - Budding yeast of Paracoccidioides with "captain's wheel" formation (much larger than RBC)

questions.text: Rubella virus belongs to which family?
questions.solution:
• Rubella virus, also known as the German measles virus, is part of the Togaviridae
  • The rubella virus has a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) genome that is positive-sense (it can be directly translated into proteins once inside a host cell).
  • The virus is enveloped, meaning it has a lipid bilayer that surrounds its RNA genome. This envelope is obtained from the host cell during the viral replication process.
  • Inside the envelope, the virus contains a protein capsid that protects the RNA genome.
  • The virus is primarily transmitted via respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
  • Incubation period 3-4 weeks
  • Rubella generally presents with a mild fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, and joint pain.
  • However, if a pregnant woman contracts rubella, it can result in severe birth defects such as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which can lead to deafness, cataracts, and heart defects in the newborn.

Incorrect options:

Option (A) Rheovirus: Rheoviruses are a family of double-stranded RNA viruses (not single-stranded RNA like rubella), and they cause diseases like gastroenteritis. Rotavirus is a rheovirus.

Option (C) Picornavirus: The picornavirus family includes viruses like poliovirus and rhinovirus, which are also RNA viruses, but they are single-stranded RNA viruses that are non-enveloped. Rubella is enveloped, and this family does not include rubella.

Option (D) Orthomyxovirus: This family includes the influenza viruses, which are RNA viruses that also have an envelope. However, orthomyxoviruses are classified differently due to their unique replication mechanisms and different disease symptoms (flu vs. rubella).

questions.text: An adult man came with dysuria, discharge from urethra with h/o unprotected sex. Best medium for this organism is
questions.solution:
Given the clinical scenario of an adult man presenting with dysuria and discharge from the urethra after unprotected sex, along with the finding of gram-negative diplococci in the Gram stain, the best culture medium for isolating this organism is:

A. Thayer Martin agar

Thayer Martin Agar: This is a selective medium specifically designed to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, which appears as gram-negative diplococci. The medium contains antibiotics that inhibit the growth of other bacteria, allowing for the selective growth of N. gonorrhoeae.

Overview of Other Options:

B. MacConkey agar: This medium is selective for gram-negative bacteria but is not specific for Neisseria  gonorrhoeae. It primarily differentiates lactose fermenters from non-fermenters.

C. Chocolate agar: While this medium supports the growth of many fastidious organisms, it is not selective for N. gonorrhoeae and is typically used for other types of bacteria.

D. TCBS agar: This medium is used primarily for isolating Vibrio species and is not suitable for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC272435/

questions.text: Most common ocular manifestations in COVID -19
questions.solution:
Follicular conjunctivitis: This is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19. It is characterized by the presence of follicles (small, raised nodules) in the conjunctiva, often accompanied by redness, watering, and irritation. It can present as bilateral conjunctivitis and is typically mild in most patients.

(A) Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: While pseudomembranous conjunctivitis (which involves the formation of a fibrous membrane on the conjunctiva) can occur in some viral infections, it is less commonly associated with COVID-19 compared to follicular conjunctivitis.

(C) Retinal vein occlusion: Retinal vein occlusion has been reported in some COVID-19 patients, but it is not a common ocular manifestation. It is typically seen in severe cases or in patients with underlying cardiovascular risk factors.

questions.text: Isotype switching occurs in which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Activated B cells undergo isotype switching after activation by helper T cells and exposure to cytokines. This switch allows the B cell to produce antibodies of different isotypes that are more appropriate for clearing the infection or neutralizing the pathogen.

(A) The helper T cells (specifically CD4+ T cells) play a crucial role in assisting B cells during this process by providing necessary signals (cytokines).

(B) Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) do not undergo isotype switching because they are not involved in antibody production; they are involved in killing infected cells.

(C) B cells refer to the progenitors of the activated B cells, but the actual switching mechanism occurs in the activated B cell, after it has encountered an antigen and received help from T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate?
questions.solution:
In above Given Image

B is an enzyme conjugate.

A is Substrate

C is Detection antibody

D is Capture antibody

This is the ELISA test. ELISA stands for Enzyme Linked Immuno Sorbent Assay.

Principle of ELISA is antigen antibody interaction. Here the specific antibodies associate or bind to its target antigen. Only when the interaction takes place the substrate can bind to the enzyme. Thereby substrate conversion can be observed. Hence positive result Is obtained.

There are many types of ELISA.

questions.text: An isolate from a cancer patient in the critical care unit is found to be resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides and sensitive to cotrimoxazole, ticarcillin-clavulanic acid. What is the likely microorganism?
questions.solution:
The pattern of resistance and sensitivity described is consistent with Acinetobacter baumannii. Acinetobacter species are notorious for their resistance to multiple antibiotics, including meropenem and aminoglycosides. They are often sensitive to cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) and ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.

(A) Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to many antibiotics, including meropenem and aminoglycosides, but typically not susceptible to cotrimoxazole. It's more commonly resistant to other beta-lactams, including ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.

(C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa typically shows resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, but it is usually not susceptible to cotrimoxazole and can show some variability with ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.

(D) Stenotrophomonas maltophila is known to be susceptible to cotrimoxazole, and this would be the first-line treatment for this pathogen. However, it's often resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides, and also has resistance to ticarcillin-clavulanic acid.

questions.text: A 60 year old male had an injury on the left hand following which his left limb turned erythematous and swollen. He has a history of renal transplant 10 years back. Masson Fontana stain was positive on the biopsy taken from his left limb. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Masson-Fontana stain highlights melanin in fungi, which is characteristic of Talaromyces marneffei, a dimorphic fungus known for producing melanin in infected tissue. It can cause subcutaneous or systemic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals like transplant patients.

(A) Aspergillus fumigatus: While Aspergillus fumigatus is a common opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. Aspergillus typically presents with pulmonary or sinus infections and not with erythematous and swollen limbs due to traumatic injury.

(C) Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomycosis is a dimorphic fungus, but it does not produce melanin. It is primarily found in North America and causes pulmonary and cutaneous infections.

(D) Bipolaris spicifera: Bipolaris is a dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus that can cause sinusitis and subcutaneous infections in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not typically produce the characteristic melanin pigmentation.

questions.text: Identify the fungus seen on histology
questions.solution:
(A) Mucor (Zygomycetes):

  • Appearance: Non-septate hyphae, broad and branch at right angles. These hyphae tend to have a ragged or angular branching pattern.
  • Key Points: The hyphae lack cross-walls (non-septate) and are often found in necrotic tissue. Mucormycosis is common in immunocompromised patients and often affects the sinuses, lungs, and brain.

(B) Conidiobolus:

  • Appearance: Non-septate hyphae with large, round conidia that can be seen in clusters at the ends of branches.
  • Key Points: Conidiobolus typically causes subcutaneous infections, especially in immunocompetent individuals. It often leads to chronic granulomatous infection with swelling or nodules, most commonly on the face and upper body.

(C) Basidiobolus:

  • Appearance: Non-septate hyphae that are similar in appearance to those of Conidiobolus but are thicker and more uniform. The conidia are often larger than those of Conidiobolus.
  • Key Points: This fungus causes subcutaneous infections, particularly in tropical regions. It presents with swollen lesions and is commonly seen in children or immunocompetent adults.

(D) Aspergillus:

  • Appearance: Septate hyphae, which are typically narrow (2-5 µm in diameter), and branch at acute angles (typically around 45 degrees). Aspergillus can form conidiophores with chains of conidia.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used in gram staining?
questions.solution:
Methylene blue is used as counter stain for acid fast stain

Gram stain:Differentiates bacteria into Gram-positive (violet) and Gram-negative(pink) groups

  • Primary stain: crystal violet (or gentian violet or methyl violet) for 1 minute.
  • Mordant: Gram's iodine for 1 minute.
  • Decolorization: acetone (for 1-2 sec) or ethanol (20-30 sec) with immediate wash. Decolorizer removes the primary stain from Gram-negative bacteria due to loss of lipid layer of cell wall while the Gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain.
  • Counter stain or Secondary stain: safranin or diluted carbol fuchsin for 30 sec.

questions.solution: Reference: CDC Guideline for Disinfection and Sterilization in Healthcare Facilities (2008)

questions.text: Sequence OF PCR:
questions.solution:
Order of sequence in PCR is

Denaturation - annealing - extension.

  1. Denaturation at 95 centigrade - this causes dsDNA to ssDNA
  2. PRIMER ANNEALING at 55 centigrade - primer anneals to complimentary site on ssDNA.
  3. EXTENSION at 72 centigrade - extension of DNA by Taq polymerase and next cycle starts

questions.text: Culture media shown in the image is an example of:
questions.solution:
• The medium shown above is of Blood agar. When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood or egg, it is called enriched medium to support the growth of fastidious organisms
  • Blood agar:
    • Prepared by adding 5-10% of sheep blood to the molten nutrient agar at 45°C.
    • It is used to test the haemolytic property of the bacteria: Alpha(partial), beta (complete) and gamma (non-haemolytic).
  • Chocolate agar:
    • It is the heated blood agar, blood is added to the molten nutrient agar at 70°C.
    • It is more nutritious than blood agar, and even supports Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Loeffler's serum slope:
    • It is used for isolation of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

B. ENRICHEMENT MEDIA;

  • Basal media +liquid nutrient like broth= enrichment media
  • Eg; selenite f broth
  • Enrichment - liquid enriched-solid enriched}

MNEMONIC

  • {liquid has more alphabets than solid, similarly enrichment has more alphabets than

C. Nutrient media is basal media for growing non fastidious organisms

D. Special media; enriched, enrichment, differential all are special media.

questions.text: Active immunity is NOT acquired by:
questions.solution:
• Active immunity: This is the resistance developed by an individual as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is also known as adaptive immunity as it represents the adaptive response of the host to a specific pathogen or other antigen.
  • Passive immunity: This is the resistance that is transmitted passively to a recipient in a 'readymade' form. Here the recipient's immune system plays no active role.

Active vs Passive immunity:

choices.text: IgE is increased in parasitic infection
Fetal infection is characterized by increase in IgG

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning immunoglobins is wrong?
questions.solution:
• IgM is the Earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus at 20 weeks.
  • IgM is Not transported across placenta due to its size.
  • lgM in fetus newborn - indicates intrauterine infections. Fetal infections are characterized by increase in IgM (not IgG).
  • First immunoglobin to appear following infections
  • IgM mediates primary (First) immune/humoral response
  • IgM is the first antibody produced and secreted by B cells during the primary and secondary immune responses.
  • IgE is increased in allergy and parasitic infections.

questions.text: An example of type I hypersensitivity is:
questions.solution:
a) Lepromin test: Type 4 Hypersensitivity

b) Tuberculin test: Type 4 Hypersensitivity

c) Casoni's test: Type 1 Hypersensitivity

d) Arthus reaction: Type 3 Hypersensitivity

  • Examples of Type I Hypersensitivity:
    • Experiments:
      • P-K reaction
      • Schultz Dale phenomenon
      • Theobald smith phenomenon
    • Systemic anaphylaxis
    • Localized anaphylaxis (atopy) such as:
      • Allergic rhinitis (or hay fever)
      • Asthma
      • Food allergy
      • Atopic urticarial
      • Atopic dermatitis (allergic eczema)
      • Drug allergy
      • Wheal and flare reaction.
    • Parasitic diseases:
      • Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE)
      • Loeffler's pneumonia (Ascaris)
      • Ground itch (Hookworm)
      • Leakage of hydatid fluid
      • Cercarial dermatitis/swimmer's itch (Schistosoma).
    • Parasitic tests:
      • Casoni test (hydatid disease)

choices.text: That activate T cells in a specific and controlled manner
Produced by antigen-presenting cells to enhance presentation capabilities
Produced by T cells as a way of increasing the antigen activation they receive from antigen-presenting cells
That activates T cells in a nonspecific and uncontrolled manner

questions.text: Superantigen is a protein molecule:
questions.solution:
• Superantigens (SAgs) are a class of antigens that result in excessive activation of the immune system. Specifically it causes non-specific activation of T-cells resulting in polyclonal T cell activation and massive cytokine release.
  • Superantigens do not get processed by an antigen- presenting cell (APC).
  • They attach directly to the MHC-II a1 domain and &beta variable chain of TCR.
  • There are two types of super-antigens: (i) endogenous, which are intracellular (e.g., virus) and (ii) exogenous, which extracellular (e.g., bacteria).

Microbial superantigens are medium-sized proteins (MW 22-29 kDa) characterised by high resistance to proteases.

They initiate the release of (IL- 2), which results in massive proliferation of T lymphocytes. This ultimately leads to further release of a variety of cytokines which have profound effect on the immune system.

Option (B): Produced by antigen-presenting cells to enhance presentation capabilities - They are protein molecules (e.g., staphylococcal enterotoxins) that activate very large numbers of T lymphocytes irrespective of their antigenic specificity. Super antigens are actually a part of bacteria or produced from bacteria but not by antigen presenting cells.

  • Option (C): Produced by T cells as a way of increasing the antigen activation they receive from antigen-presenting cells - Super antigens are actually a part of bacteria or produced from bacteria but not by T cells.

choices.text: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for MRSA
The resistance is because of the kagA gene
MRSA are detected by using a cefoxitin disk

questions.text: All of the following are true for MRSA except:
questions.solution:
• Methicillin resistance in S. aureus is mediated by a chromosomally encoded gene called mecA gene, which alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell membrane to PBP2a.
  • OTHER options:
  • Option A) Vancomycin is the drug of choice for MRSA.
  • Alternative drugs include-teicoplanin, linezolid, daptomycin, telavancin and quinupristin/dalfopristin.
  • C) MRSA are either community or hospital associated.
  • Option D) Antimicrobial susceptibility test using cefoxitin disk or oxacillin (MIC based method): These antibiotics are used as a surrogate marker for the identification of MRSA
  • PCR detecting mecA gene
  • Latex agglutination test detecting PBP2a.

questions.text: A butcher presented with seal finger. What is the drug of choice to treat seal finger?
questions.solution:
• Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a gram-positive bacillus that causes erysipeloid; characterized by violaceous swelling with severe pain, but no pus; which differentiates it from staphylococcal and streptococcal erysipelas where pus is seen at the infection site. Most common site is fingers (called "seal finger" and "whale finger").
  • Transmission: It usually infects animal handlers (abattoir workers, butchers) and fishermen; transmitted by direct inoculation from animals or animal products.
  • Treatment: Penicillin G is the drug of choice for severe infections.

choices.text: Reduce duration of therapy to 4 months

questions.text: What would be the next step in a known patient of LL experiencing new painful lesions on his skin?
questions.solution:
• This case describes a case of type-2 lepra reaction, which is a type -3 hypersensitivity to lepra antigens.
  • It is characterized by painful new crops of lesions, known as Lucio phenomena and may/may not occur during the course of therapy.
  • Type 2 reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) occurs in the LL and BL types, usually a few months after the institution of chemotherapy. Crops of tender, inflamed subcutaneous nodules appear, with fever, lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. This is an Arthus-type response to antigens released from dead lepra cells, which is characterised by neutrophil infiltration and IgG and complement deposition in the lesions.
  • Its treatment is to continue with the drugs and add steroids.
  • Option (A): Stopping anti-leprosy therapy is not advisable, as the patient is experiencing an exacerbation. Instead, we can manage the exacerbation with corticosteroids while continuing the anti-leprosy treatment to ensure the disease remains effectively treated.
  • Option (C): Reduce duration of therapy to 4 months - Reducing the duration of therapy to 4 months is not advisable, as it could lead to incomplete treatment and allow the disease to persist in the patient.
  • Option D): Change rifampicin to rifabutin - this This type 2 reaction is not an indication to change the medication, as drug resistance would be a more relevant reason for modifying the treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following infections caused by Yersinia Pestis shows man to man transmission?
questions.solution:
Pneumonic plague is the only infection caused by Y. pestis which shows man to man transmission. The others are zoonoses.

Pneumonic plague may sometimes be seen during epidemics of bubonic plague. Rarely, primary pneumonic plague may occur in epidemic form, as happened in Manchuria in 1910-1 912, causing some 60,000 deaths. Pneumonic plague is spread by droplet infection. The bacilli spread through the lungs producing hemorrhagic pneumonia. Cyanosis is very prominent. The bloody mucoid sputum that is coughed out contains bacilli in enormous numbers. Pneumonic plague is highly infectious and in untreated patients, almost invariably fatal.

Option (A): Bubonic Plague - In bubonic plague,after an incubation period of 2-5 days, the lymph nodes draining the site of entry of the bacillus become infected. In some, the infection remains localised at the site of the flea bite, with only minor constitutional symptoms (pestis minor). As the plague bacillus usually enters through flea bites on the legs, the inguinal nodes are involved and hence the name ' bubonic'.

Option (C): Septicaemic Plague - Septicaemic plague is usually the terminal event in the bubonic or pneumonic plague but may sometimes occur primarily. Meningitic involvement may occur rarely. Human carriers have not been recorded but asymptomatic oropharyngeal infection has been observed in some contacts.

questions.text: B.quintana most commonly causes:
questions.solution:
• Quintana: It is transmitted by louse.
  • It is the agent of - Trench fever: It occurred as epidemics in the trenches during World War I.
  • It is a mild febrile illness which lasts for five days, subsequent episodes occurring every 5 days (hence also called as 5 days fever). Thereafter, it was found to be silent for decades.
  • B.quintana causes trench fever or 5 days fever. Trench fever is an exclusively human disease and no animal reservoir is known. It is transmitted by the body louse. The feces of lice become infectious 5-10 days after an infectious meal. The lice are unharmed and remain infective throughout their lives. Vertical transmission does not occur in lice.
  • However, the disease has re-emerged in USA recently.

questions.text: The colonies of mycoplasma are examined by which of the following stains?
questions.solution:
For mycoplasma:

  • In liquid medium (containing PPLO broth): M. pneumoniae growth is detected by turbidity and a color change.
  • In solid medium (containing PPLO agar): The colonies appear very small (200-500 μm size), embedded on agar surface described as fried egg appearance colonies.
  • The colonies can be examined by hand lens or use of special stain such as Dienes' staining (nonspecific stain that imparts color to Mycoplasma colonies on agar).

choices.text: Dacron swabs are used for specimen collection in Gonorrhea
Amie's / Stuart's media is used as transport media of Gonorrhea specimens
For a specimen in Gonorrhea urethral swabs are taken in male and vaginal swabs in females
Cotton alginate swabs are inhibitory to Gonorrhea

questions.text: Identify the false statement.
questions.solution:
For Gonorrhea:

  • Urethral swab in men and cervical swab in women are the preferred specimens. Vaginal swab is not satisfactory. Because the vaginal mucusa is not usually affected in adults because the stratifiedsquamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • The urethral meatus is cleaned with gauze soaked in saline. The purulent discharge is expressed by pressing at the base of the penis and collected directly on to slides or swabs.
  • Dacron or rayon swabs are preferred, as cotton alginate swabs are inhibitory to gonococci.
  • ln chronic urethritis: As discharge is minimal, prostate massage is done to collect the secretion; alternatively, the morning drop of secretion may be collected.
  • Transport media: Stuarts and Amies transport medium.

questions.text: Which virus has an envelope composed of nuclear membrane molecules?
questions.solution:
• Shingles is a dermatomal rash with painful blistering caused by reactivation of the varicella zoster virus, which belongs to the family of herpesviruses.
  • Herpesviruses are the only viruses that acquire their envelope from host cell nuclear membranes; other viruses acquire their envelope from host cellplasma membranes.
  • Because immune cells do not typically attack host cell nuclei, this envelope aids in viral evasion of the immune response.
  • Rash distribution
    • Unilateral Rash
    • Segmental because of dermatomal distribution (most common D3 to L2)
    • Painful
  • Complications
    • Post herpetic neuralgia
    • Zoster ophthalmicus
    • Ramsay hunt syndrome

Envelope

  • Most viruses contain envelopes.
  • Some are non- enveloped viruses.
    • DNA viruses
    • Parvovirus
    • Adenovirus
    • Papova virus
    • RNA viruses
    • Picornavirus
    • Astrovirus
    • Reovirus
    • Calicivirus
    • Hepatitis A
    • Hepatitis E

choices.text: No need to treat her, go for delivery as normal
Give vzig to pregnant female and to the baby after born

questions.text: A 40week pregnant female with expected EDD In 2 days complained that her mother- in- law got chickenpox. she is concerned about her baby now. what should be the advice to be given to her
questions.solution:
Any pregnant female on exposure to chicken pox should receive VZIG because varicella vaccine is contraindicated in them, as it is a live vaccine.

Here in question EDD is within 2 days, so the baby should also receive VZIG.

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS OF CHICKEN POX;

Oka strain varicella vaccine should be given with 5 days

Contraindications of vaccine:

  • Pregnant female
  • Neonate- exposed 5 days before delivery to 2 days after delivery

(If the baby develops chickenpox after 2 days, it means the baby was not infected during delivery but was infected later, outside the genital tract, from the mother. This is known as postnatal varicella syndrome).

  • Immunocompromised person (CD4 count< 200)

If exposed, then we will give them VZIG (varicella zoster immunoglobulin) within 3 days.

questions.text: What will be the serological profile of a patient infected with acute HBV during its maximum infectivity period?
questions.solution:
During the acute phase of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, particularly during the period of maximum infectivity both HBsAg and HBeAg are elevated.

  • HBsAg (Hepatitis B Surface Antigen): This antigen appears early in the infection and is the hallmark of active HBV infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infected with HBV and is infectious. During the acute phase of infection, HBsAg is typically positive.
  • HBeAg (Hepatitis B e Antigen): HBeAg is a marker of high viral replication and indicates a highly infectious state. The presence of HBeAg signifies that the virus is actively replicating and that the individual has a high viral load, contributing to maximum infectivity during the acute phase.

(A): Anti-HBsAg +, Anti-HBeAg +: These antibodies develop later, during recovery or immune clearance.

(B): HBsAg -, HBeAg -: This would indicate a non-infectious state or resolution of the infection.

(D): Anti-HBs +, HBeAg +: It would appear later, after the immune system has started to clear the virus, whereas HBeAg is present during active infection.
